--- title: "EIA vs EBM" author: "David Beauchesne" date: "2024-06-15" categories: [cumulative effects] image: "wordcloud.png" draft: false execute: warning: false format: html: code-fold: true code-summary: "Code" --- ::: {.cell} ::: In my latest post, I performed semantic analyses on a [literature review centered on cumulative effects assessment](../review_scientific_literature/). In this post, I want to dive deeper in this review and contrast three different fields of research that regularly cite the assessment of cumulative effects in their respective process: environmental impact assessment, ecosystem-based management and multiple stressors experiments. The assessment of cumulative effects through an environmental impact assessment is usually centered on project-specific appraisal and acceptance unless it is a regional assessment. Cumulative effects viewed through the lense of ecosystem-based management, meanwhile, are more holistic in scope, are usually performed at larger spatial scales and are concerned with the management and monitoring of whole regions. This encompasses processes such as strategic conservation planning and marine spatial planning, which are essentially ecosystem-based management approaches. For more information on these two fields, you can read my blog post that details [what are cumulative effects](../what_are_cumulative_effects/). Not covered in my previous post is a third area that focuses on the cumulative effects of multiple stressors. This field typically explores how various stressors, when combined, impact the environment or organisms. Researchers in this area often conduct controlled experiments involving two or three stressors to observe their effects on ecological processes (*e.g.* growth, mortality) for specific organisms or groups of organisms. These experiments are crucial for understanding non-additive effects, such as antagonistic effects, where stressors counteract each other, and synergistic effects, where stressors amplify each other's impact. Findings from these studies are much more contextual and have limited applicability for large scale environmental management, although researchers in that field may disagree with this statement. The three fields of research all shape how managers approach cumulative effects. They borrow concepts and keywords from each field, often expecting the best of all three when discussing these effects. Based on my experience in ecosystem-based cumulative effects assessment, I've noticed two recurring questions that stem from the other fields: From the multiple stressors field: - "We know that stressors do not always combine additively. How are you considering non-additive effects in your assessment?" From the environmental impact assessment field: - "What is the significance and the uncertainty associated with your assessment?" Conversely, the other fields are plagued by questions stemming from ecosystem-based management: To the multiple stressors field: - "There are many more stressors and organisms in an ecosystem. How can your results be used to predict synergistic effects for all combinations of stressors and organisms in an ecosystem?" To the environmental impact assessment field: - "Your assessment covers a single project in a region impacted by numerous other projects and industries on top of climate change. How does your assessment account for these additional effects?" These are all valid questions that highlight the interconnectedness of these fields. However, no single field can answer all environmental management questions. It's crucial for those emphasizing the importance of cumulative effects to understand the limitations of these research areas, the types of answers they can provide, and which field to consult based on the specific management question. The goal of this post is therefore to begin highlighting the differences between these research fields based on the published literature. # Screening the literature After programmatically exploring the results of the literature search in [my previous post](../review_scientific_literature/), I manually screened and tagged all the peer-reviewed articles. For this post, I was mostly interested in identifying the process each article was interested in (*i.e.* environmental impacts assessment vs ecosystem-based management vs multiple stressors), the types of ecosystem they worked on (*i.e.* marine, terrestrial or freshwater), and the countries where the work was performed. Through this work, I also removed some articles that made it through the programmatic filtering process done previously but that should have been removed. ## Keywords ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Bibliographies lit <- bib2df::bib2df("cea_screen.bib", separate_names = TRUE, merge_lines = TRUE) |> # lit <- bib2df::bib2df("series/posts/cumulative_effects/eia_vs_ebm/cea_screen.bib", separate_names = TRUE, merge_lines = TRUE) |> mutate( uid = row_number(), DATE = lubridate::as_date(DATE, format = lubridate::guess_formats(DATE, c("Y", "Y-m-d", "Y-m"))), year = lubridate::year(DATE) ) # Countries # countries <- vroom::vroom("series/posts/cumulative_effects/eia_vs_ebm/cea_countries.csv", delim = ",") countries <- vroom::vroom("cea_countries.csv", delim = ",") # Keywords key <- lit |> select(uid, KEYWORDS) |> reframe(key = unlist(stringr::str_split(KEYWORDS, ",")), .by = c(uid)) |> tidyr::drop_na() |> mutate(key = tolower(stringr::str_trim(key, side = "both"))) |> filter(key != "") |> filter(!key %in% c("skimmed", "to read", "read again")) # Table of keywords table(key$key) |> as.data.frame() |> arrange(desc(Freq)) |> knitr::kable(col.names = c("Keywords", "Frequency")) |> kableExtra::scroll_box(width = "55%", height = "500px") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}

````` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # # Table of keywords that I specifically used in my research # key |> # filter(key %in% c("ebm", "eia", "marine", "freshwater", "terrestrial", "case study", "data", "geospatial", "health", "indigenous", "legislation", "management", "method", "problem", "process", "rea", "review", "risk", "roles", "social", "sea", "sen", "solution")) |> # count(key) |> # arrange(desc(n)) |> # knitr::kable(col.names = c("Keywords", "Frequency")) |> # kableExtra::scroll_box(width = "55%", height = "500px") ``` ::: ## The fight of the fields ### Published articles The screening process allowed me to differentiate between the different fields of research. For a total of 275 published articles, here is the breakdown of the number of articles per research fields. ::: {.cell tab-cap='Number of articles published per fields of research'} ```{.r .cell-code} dat <- filter(key, key %in% c("eia", "ebm", "multiple stressors")) |> mutate(key = case_when(key == "multiple stressors" ~ "ms", .default = key)) |> group_by(uid) |> mutate(key = paste(key, collapse = " & ")) |> ungroup() |> count(key) |> mutate( uid = 1:n(), A = stringr::str_detect(key, "eia"), B = stringr::str_detect(key, "ebm"), C = stringr::str_detect(key, "ms"), ) |> tidyr::pivot_longer(col = c(A, B, C), names_to = "sets", values_to = "tmp") |> filter(tmp) |> group_by(uid) |> group_split() |> lapply(function(x) { list( name = x$key[1], sets = as.list(x$sets), value = x$n[1] ) }) library(highcharter) highchart() %>% hc_chart(type = "venn") %>% hc_add_series( dataLabels = list(style = list(fontSize = "20px")), name = "Venn Diagram", data = dat ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: ### Timeline Let us now look at the timeline of published articles concerned with each fields to investigate whether the fields appeared at different periods. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} dat <- left_join( lit[, c("uid", "year")], filter(key, key %in% c("eia", "ebm", "multiple stressors")), by = "uid" ) |> group_by(year, key) |> summarize(n = n()) timeline <- tidyr::expand_grid( key = c("eia", "ebm", "multiple stressors"), year = min(dat$year):max(dat$year) ) |> left_join(dat, by = c("key", "year")) |> mutate(n = case_when(is.na(n) ~ 0, .default = n)) |> group_by(key) |> arrange(key, year) |> mutate(cumcount = cumsum(n)) |> mutate(key = case_when( key == "eia" ~ "Environmental Impact Assessment", key == "ebm" ~ "Ecosystem-Based Management", .default = "Multiple Stressors" )) # Chart timeline |> echarts4r::e_charts(year) |> echarts4r::e_line( cumcount, smooth = TRUE, symbol = "none", endLabel = list(show = TRUE, formatter = "{a}"), labelLayout = list(x = "92%", moveOverlap = "shiftY"), emphasis = list(focus = "series"), ) |> echarts4r::e_x_axis(min = 1985, max = 2024, formatter = echarts4r::e_axis_formatter(digits = 0)) |> echarts4r::e_tooltip(trigger = "axis", order = "valueDesc") |> echarts4r::e_animation(duration = 10000) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` Number of articles citing cumulative effects assessment published through the environmental impact assessment, ecosystem-based management and multiple stressors research fields. ::: ::: ### Ecosystems While manually screening the published literature, I identified the broad types of ecosystems with which the articles were concerned, *i.e.* marine vs continental (*i.e.* including terrestrial, freshwater and watershed assessments). Let us look whether there is a discrepancy between the research fields. Looking at those results, there is a clear discrepancy between the ecosystem-based management and environmental impact assessment fields, with the later predominantly concerned with marine assessments, while the latter is more concerned with continental assessments. The multiple stressors field, meanwhile, is closer to parity, with a slight edge towards marine assessments. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ecosystem <- left_join( key |> filter(key %in% c("eia", "ebm", "multiple stressors")) |> rename(field = key), key |> mutate(key = case_when( key %in% c("terrestrial", "freshwater") ~ "continental", .default = key )) |> filter(key %in% c("marine", "continental")) |> rename(ecosystem = key), by = "uid", relationship = "many-to-many" ) |> na.omit() |> group_by(field, ecosystem) |> count() |> group_by(field) |> mutate( total = sum(n), n_rel = round(n / total, 2) ) |> mutate(field = case_when( field == "eia" ~ "Environmental Impact Assessment", field == "ebm" ~ "Ecosystem-Based Management", .default = "Multiple Stressors" )) ecosystem |> group_by(ecosystem) |> echarts4r::e_charts(field) |> echarts4r::e_bar(n_rel) |> echarts4r::e_tooltip(trigger = "axis", order = "valueDesc") |> echarts4r::e_y_axis( formatter = echarts4r::e_axis_formatter("percent") ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` Percent number of articles citing cumulative effects assessment published through the environmental impact assessment, ecosystem-based management and multiple stressors research fields concerned with marine or continental ecosystems. ::: ::: ### Countries ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} cns0 <- countrycode::codelist$country.name.en cns <- data.frame(country = cns0) |> left_join( key |> mutate(key = stringr::str_to_title(key)) |> filter(key %in% cns0), by = c("country" = "key"), relationship = "many-to-many" ) |> mutate( eia = case_when(uid %in% key$uid[key$key == "eia"] ~ TRUE, .default = FALSE), ebm = case_when(uid %in% key$uid[key$key == "ebm"] ~ TRUE, .default = FALSE), ms = case_when(uid %in% key$uid[key$key == "multiple stressors"] ~ TRUE, .default = FALSE), marine = case_when(uid %in% key$uid[key$key == "marine"] ~ TRUE, .default = FALSE), continental = case_when(uid %in% key$uid[key$key %in% c("terrestrial", "freshwater")] ~ TRUE, .default = FALSE) ) # Figure per country dat <- cns |> group_by(country) |> summarize(value = n()) dat |> echarts4r::e_charts(country) |> echarts4r::e_map(value, roam = TRUE) |> echarts4r::e_visual_map(value, color = viridis::magma(100)) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` Number of articles citing cumulative effects assessment published through the environmental impact assessment, ecosystem-based management and multiple stressors research fields by countries. ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # Figure per country per field of research cns |> group_by(country) |> summarise_at(c("eia", "ebm", "ms"), sum) |> left_join(dat, by = "country") |> mutate(eia = eia / value, ebm = ebm / value, ms = ms / value) |> select(-value) |> tidyr::pivot_longer(-country, names_to = "field", values_to = "value") |> mutate(field = case_when( field == "eia" ~ "Environmental Impact Assessment", field == "ebm" ~ "Ecosystem-Based Management", .default = "Multiple Stressors" )) |> group_by(field) |> echarts4r::e_charts(country, timeline = TRUE) |> echarts4r::e_map(value, roam = TRUE) |> echarts4r::e_visual_map(value, color = viridis::magma(100)) |> echarts4r::e_timeline_serie( title = list( list(text = "Environmental Impact Assessment", subtext = "Percent number of articles published"), list(text = "Ecosystem-Based Management", subtext = "Percent number of articles published"), list(text = "Multiple Stressors", subtext = "Percent number of articles published") ) ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` Percent number of articles citing cumulative effects assessment published through the environmental impact assessment, ecosystem-based management and multiple stressors research fields by countries per field of research. ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # Figure per country per ecosystem cns |> group_by(country) |> summarise_at(c("marine", "continental"), sum) |> left_join(dat, by = "country") |> mutate(marine = marine / value, continental = continental / value) |> select(-value) |> tidyr::pivot_longer(-country, names_to = "ecosystem", values_to = "value") |> mutate(ecosystem = stringr::str_to_sentence(ecosystem)) |> group_by(ecosystem) |> echarts4r::e_charts(country, timeline = TRUE) |> echarts4r::e_map(value, roam = TRUE) |> echarts4r::e_visual_map(value, color = viridis::magma(100)) |> echarts4r::e_timeline_serie( title = list( list(text = "Marine ecosystems", subtext = "Percent number of articles published"), list(text = "Continental ecosystems", subtext = "Percent number of articles published") ) ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` Percent number of articles citing cumulative effects assessment published through the environmental impact assessment, ecosystem-based management and multiple stressors research fields by countries per ecosystem. ::: :::
